task.title: Log In to the User Console

context.p: The purpose of this section of the lab is only to learn how to navigate in the User Console interface and to see what types of actions and information are available. Later lab exercises will teach you to use specific User Console functionality to create key pairs, launch instances, and manage storage, network, and security resources.

With the User Console service installed, configured, and running, you will open a browser and log in to the User Console. Once in the User Console you will explore the interface without making changes. Later labs will explain User Console operations and provide hands-on experience using the interface.

step.cmd: On the Debian desktop, open the browser and connect to the User Console using the URL https://<front_end_public_IP:8888. Because the User Console server uses a self-signed certificate, you will need to confirm the security of the connection to the browser.
At the login window, sign in to the cloud as the user normal in the sales account using the password of passwordNN, where NN is the number of your student pod. Then click Log In.

info.p: The Dashboard window will appear on your screen.

step.cmd: View the types of information available to you in the Dashboard window of the User Console and answer the following questions. Do not make changes at this time.

info.p: How many Running and Stopped instances do you have in your cloud?
How many Volumes and Snapshots do you have in your cloud?
How many Security Groups do you have in your cloud?
How many Key Pairs do you have in your cloud?
How my public IP Addresses do you have in your cloud?

step.cmd: In the Dashboard window of the User Console, click the help (?) icon in the top-right corner.

info.p: The help window for the Dashboard opens. The help icons in each window are context-sensitive and display help information relative to the current window.

step.cmd: In the help window, click the icon that will open a separate help window and return you to the Dashboard window.
In the Dashboard window of the User Console, click the help (?) icon in the top-right corner again.
In the help window, click the icon that will return you to the Dashboard window.
In the User Console, click the Images icon.

info.p: The Manage Images window opens. How many images are in your cloud?

step.cmd: In the Manage Images window, click the help icon in the top-right corner.

info.p: Is the help window that opens different from the Dashboard help window that you opened earlier?

step.cmd: Click the return icon to return to the Manage Images window.
In the User Console, click the Instances icon.

info.p: The Manage instances window opens. How many instances are in your cloud?

step.cmd: In the User Console, click once on the Storage icon.

info.p: What drop-down menu choices appear on your screen?

step.cmd: On the Storage drop-down menu, click Volumes.

info.p: The Manage volumes window opens. How many volumes do you have?

step.cmd: On the Storage drop-down menu, click Snapshots.

info.p: The Manage snapshots window opens. How many snapshots do you have?

step.cmd: On the Network & Security drop-down menu, click Security Groups.

info.p: The Manage security groups window opens. How many security groups do you have? Do they have names?

step.cmd: On the Network & Security drop-down menu, click Key Pairs.
step.info: The Manage key pairs window opens. How many key pairs do you have?

step.cmd: On the Network & Security drop-down menu, click IP Addresses.

info.p: The Manage IP addresses window opens. How many public IP addresses have been allocated (reserved) by the user normal in the cloud?

step.cmd: Remain logged in to the User Console.
